author: boston.com
title: Study warns hands-free car systems still distract drivers - Massachusetts news
text:
With Massachusetts considering legislation banning the use of hand-held mobile devices while driving, a study released Thursday finds that hands-free car systems can be just as distracting.
According to research by AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety, “new hands-free technologies can mentally distract drivers even if their eyes are on the road and their hands are on the wheel,” with persisting effects lasting from 15 to 27 seconds depending on the hands-free system used.
The study found that in-car voice command systems, such as Apple’s Siri or Google Now, were as distracting as sending a voice-activated text. The worst-performing hands-free system, found in the Mazda 6, provided the same level of distraction as updating social media while driving, the study found.
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below “Motorists could miss stop signs, pedestrians and other vehicles while the mind is readjusting to the task of driving,” Peter Kissinger, president and CEO of the foundation, said in a statement.
Though the Bay State banned texting while driving in 2010, it is one of three New England states , along with Maine and Rhode Island, that still allow drivers to pick up their phones and make a call.
The ban on hand-held mobile devices while driving in New Hampshire, the “Live Free or Die State,” went into effect July 1 , months after Vermont’s hand-held ban became law in October 2014. Connecticut, New York, and New Jersey also ban hand-held devices while driving.
Massachusetts lawmakers are currently considering legislation that would make the use of hand-held phones while driving illegal, though two similar bills have failed recently on Beacon Hill.
Mary Maguire, the director of public and governmental affairs for AAA Southern New England, told Boston.com that the group supports hands-free cell phone bills in Massachusetts, even if they don’t make things completely risk-free.
“We testified in favor because we believe it’s the only way to enforce the critically important texting ban,” Maguire said. “That being said, we believe hands-free is only part of the solution because hands-free is not risk-free.”
Rep. William Straus, who introduced a hands-free law this session, told the Associated Press in October he expects a public hearing on his bill this fall.
“There is no personal liberty to create unnecessary hazards for other members of the public,” Straus said.
